slides.text: Geometry is mathematics you can see and touch. Every time you measure a room for furniture, calculate paint for a wall, or figure out how much a container holds, you are using these exact skills. They are among the most practically useful math skills you will ever learn.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student correctly apply perimeter, area, and volume formulas, choose the appropriate measurement for real-world problems, and use correct units?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up our geometry review! Remember how you measured things, figured out how much space they cover, or how much they hold? That's geometry in action, and it's super useful for everything from decorating your room to figuring out how much food to buy. You totally rocked it by learning how to choose the right measurement and use the right formulas!

parent_notes: Geometry review is an excellent opportunity for hands-on practice. Have your child measure actual rooms (perimeter and area), calculate how much paint would be needed for a wall, or figure out the volume of a storage box. These real applications make the formulas meaningful. If your child struggles to remember formulas, help them create a formula card they can reference. The key skill is not memorization but knowing when to use each formula. The mixed problems where they must choose the correct measurement are the most important part of this lesson.

title: Year-End Timeline Project — Adding Depth and Personal Connections
description: Students continue their comprehensive timeline by adding illustrations, personal reflections, and connections to their own lives. They explore how historical events still shape the world they live in and add a 'personal timeline' track showing their own life in the context of history.
instructions:
1. Review the timeline from last session and identify areas that need more detail.
2. Add illustrations: draw key figures, events, or symbols for major moments.
3. Write brief captions for each event explaining its significance in 1-2 sentences.
4. Create a 'personal timeline' track at the bottom showing the student's own life events.
5. Draw connections between historical events and things that affect the student's life today.
6. Identify historical 'turning points' — moments where history could have gone a different way.
7. Add notable inventions, discoveries, and cultural achievements alongside political events.
8. Discuss which era the student would most want to visit and why.
9. Write a reflection: 'How has studying history changed the way I see the world?'
10. Plan the timeline's final presentation format.

slides.heading: Year-End Timeline Project
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is just the big title for our project! It's called the "Year-End Timeline Project," and the cool part is that we're going to make it way more than just a list of dates. We're adding personal stuff and showing how history still affects us today.

slides.setup_instructions: Carefully lay out the in-progress timeline. Gather all history notes and reference materials. Print small images of key historical figures and events for adding to the timeline.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us what supplies we'll need to make our timelines awesome. We've got our timeline from last time, colorful markers for drawing, printed pictures to stick on, glue sticks to hold everything down, and special paper for our thoughts. Make sure you have all these things ready to go so we can get started!

slides.text: Your timeline shows WHAT happened. Today we add WHY it matters. For each major event, write a brief caption: not just 'The Renaissance began' but 'The Renaissance began, sparking an explosion of art, science, and new ideas that still shape our world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, our timeline has the *what* that happened, but this step is all about the *why* it matters. For each big event, we're going to write a short sentence explaining its importance. Think about how it didn't just happen, but how it led to other things or changed the world, like how the invention of the internet changed everything.

slides.text: Add a personal timeline track at the bottom. Mark your birth, key life events, and today. Then draw arrows connecting historical events to your daily life. The rights you have, the technology you use, the languages you speak — all have historical roots.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to add a super cool part: your own life story right at the bottom of the timeline! Put in your birthday and any big moments, then draw lines showing how those history events connect to your life. For example, maybe a law about fairness connects to why you get to play sports.

slides.text: Identify TURNING POINTS: moments where a different decision could have changed everything. What if Columbus had not received funding? What if the Industrial Revolution had started in China instead of England? These 'what if' questions show that history was not inevitable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about thinking like a detective and finding "turning points" in history. These are moments where if one small thing had gone differently, history would have totally changed. Imagine if someone had decided *not* to invent the car – our whole world would be so different, right?

slides.text: History is not just wars and politics. Add inventions (printing press, steam engine, internet), discoveries (gravity, germs, DNA), and cultural achievements (great literature, music, art movements) to your timeline. These often matter more than battles.
slides.mascot_explanation: History isn't just about battles and leaders; this slide reminds us to add all the amazing inventions, discoveries, and art that people created. Things like the printing press or incredible music made a huge impact, sometimes even more than wars, so let's add those to our timeline too.

slides.prompt: Enhance your timeline with: (1) Illustrations or printed images for at least 10 events. (2) Captions explaining significance for 8 key events. (3) A personal timeline track with connections to at least 3 historical events. (4) At least 2 'turning points' marked and explained. Write a one-paragraph reflection: How has studying history this year changed the way you see the world?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our main activity where we put everything together! You need to add pictures for at least 10 events, write explanations for 8 of them, add your personal timeline with at least 3 connections, and mark 2 turning points. Then, write a quick paragraph about how learning history has changed how you see things.

slides.text: Your timeline is becoming a work of historical scholarship. By connecting events across eras and to your own life, you are seeing what historians see: history is not a dead subject about the past — it is the living context that shapes everything about the present.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student add meaningful detail to their timeline, connect historical events to their personal life, identify turning points, and articulate how studying history has changed their perspective?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! Your timeline is way more than just dates now; it's a story showing how events from long ago connect to your own life and shape the world today. You've really learned how history isn't just in books, but it's alive all around us.

parent_notes: The personal connections are the most meaningful part of this project. Help your child see how their daily life connects to historical events: the technology they use (Industrial Revolution, Digital Revolution), the rights they enjoy (Enlightenment, civil rights movement), the food they eat (Columbian Exchange, agricultural revolution). The reflection question is profound — take time to discuss it as a family. Store the timeline carefully; it will be a centerpiece of the year-end presentation.

title: Environmental Geography — Human Impact on Earth Systems
description: Students examine how human activities affect Earth's major systems: atmosphere (climate change), hydrosphere (water pollution), lithosphere (deforestation, mining), and biosphere (habitat loss, extinction). They analyze data and explore sustainable solutions.
instructions:
1. Review Earth's four spheres: atmosphere, hydrosphere, lithosphere, biosphere.
2. Discuss how human activities have grown in scale: from local farming to global industry.
3. Examine atmospheric impact: greenhouse gases, climate change, and the data behind global temperature rise.
4. Examine hydrosphere impact: water pollution sources, ocean acidification, freshwater scarcity.
5. Examine lithosphere impact: deforestation, soil erosion, mining, and urban sprawl.
6. Examine biosphere impact: habitat loss, species extinction rates, invasive species.
7. Analyze a graph showing the acceleration of human environmental impact since the Industrial Revolution.
8. Explore sustainable solutions: renewable energy, conservation, recycling, sustainable agriculture.
9. Students create an environmental impact diagram showing problems and solutions for each sphere.
10. Write a personal action plan: five things you can do to reduce your environmental impact.

slides.heading: Environmental Geography
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page for our lesson. It's called "Environmental Geography" and it's all about how what we humans do affects our planet, like the air we breathe, the water, the land, and all the living things.

slides.setup_instructions: Print data graphs showing temperature trends, deforestation rates, and species extinction rates. Have the Earth systems diagram visible. Prepare the sustainable solutions reference sheet.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide tells us what we'll need for our activity. We've got a diagram of the Earth's systems, some graphs with data about the environment, a world map, colored pencils for drawing, and a science journal to write in. Make sure you have all these ready, and maybe ask a grown-up to help print out the data graphs if you need to.

slides.text: Humans have always changed their environment. But since the Industrial Revolution, the scale and speed of change has accelerated dramatically. Today we examine how our activities affect all four of Earth's systems.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like our starting point. It reminds us that people have always changed the world around them, but since we started building factories and using machines a long time ago, we've been changing things way faster and on a much bigger scale. Today, we're going to look at how all these changes affect the planet's main parts.

slides.text: The ATMOSPHERE: burning fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide, which traps heat. Global temperatures have risen about 1.1 degrees Celsius since 1900. That sounds small, but it is enough to melt glaciers, raise sea levels, and intensify storms.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're focusing on the atmosphere, which is the air all around us. When we burn things like coal and gas for energy, we release a gas called carbon dioxide, which acts like a blanket, trapping heat and making the whole planet warmer. Even a small temperature rise can cause big problems like melting ice and stronger storms.

slides.text: The HYDROSPHERE: factories, farms, and cities send pollutants into rivers and oceans. Plastic pollution fills the oceans. Meanwhile, many regions face freshwater shortages as demand exceeds supply and aquifers are depleted.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at the hydrosphere – that's all the water on Earth, like rivers, lakes, and oceans. Factories and farms can release yucky stuff into the water, and all that plastic trash we see in the ocean is a huge problem. Plus, in some places, there just isn't enough clean water for everyone.

slides.text: The good news: solutions exist. Renewable energy (solar, wind) can replace fossil fuels. Sustainable agriculture can feed people without destroying soil. Conservation can protect habitats. Recycling reduces waste. Each solution tackles a specific problem.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the good news slide! It tells us that even though we have these big environmental problems, there are awesome solutions. Things like using power from the sun and wind instead of burning fossil fuels, growing food in ways that don't hurt the soil, protecting animal homes, and recycling our trash can all help fix things.

slides.prompt: Create a four-quadrant environmental impact diagram. In each quadrant (atmosphere, hydrosphere, lithosphere, biosphere): (1) Identify the main human impacts. (2) List the consequences. (3) Propose at least two sustainable solutions. Then write a personal environmental action plan listing five specific things you can do in your daily life to reduce your impact.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be creative! You'll make a big drawing with four sections, one for each of Earth's systems. In each section, you'll write down how people are hurting that system, what happens because of it, and then list at least two cool solutions. After that, you'll write down five things *you* can do every day to help out.

slides.text: Understanding human impact is not about guilt — it is about empowerment. When you understand the problems, you can be part of the solutions. The choices you make — what you buy, how you travel, what you eat — have real environmental consequences. You have the knowledge to make informed decisions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify human impacts on all four Earth systems, analyze environmental data, propose sustainable solutions, and create a personal action plan?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is a reminder that learning about environmental problems isn't about feeling bad; it's about realizing you have the power to help. Every choice you make, from what you eat to how you get around, makes a difference, and now you know how to make smarter choices for the planet.

parent_notes: Environmental topics can feel overwhelming for children. Balance honesty about the challenges with genuine hope about solutions. Emphasize that individual actions matter AND that systemic change is needed — both are true. Your child's personal action plan should include things they can actually do, not just abstract goals. If possible, implement one of their actions as a family this week. This lesson connects science, geography, and civic engagement, showing how different disciplines address the same issues from different angles.

title: Holes — Chapters 31-End: Justice, Redemption, and the Full Circle
description: Students finish reading 'Holes,' witnessing the resolution of all three storylines. They analyze how Sachar brings every thread together, discuss themes of justice and redemption, and evaluate the book's message about fate, friendship, and breaking cycles of injustice.
instructions:
1. Review the major plot threads that need resolution.
2. Read the remaining chapters aloud, savoring the revelations.
3. Discuss the treasure discovery: What was it? How do all the family stories connect to it?
4. Analyze the Warden's true motivation and how it connects to Kate Barlow.
5. Discuss Zero's identity reveal: How does this complete the circle of the Yelnats and Zeroni families?
6. Examine the ending: Is justice served? Does the 'curse' really break?
7. Revisit the question of fate versus free will in the novel.
8. Evaluate the book as a whole: What makes it a Newbery Medal winner?
9. Students write a book review that evaluates the craft, themes, and impact of the novel.
10. Discuss: What will you remember most about this book?

slides.heading: Holes — Final Chapters
slides.subheading: Justice, Redemption, and the Full Circle
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is like the cover of the final act of our story, "Holes." It's telling us that we're heading into the part where everything that's been happening – all the mysteries and the different stories – are finally going to wrap up. We're talking about things like justice, second chances, and how everything comes full circle.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Pull out the storyline timeline and character chart for final updates. Print the book review template.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our toolbox for finishing the book. We've got the actual "Holes" book, of course, and our reading journal where we've been writing down our thoughts. Then there's the storyline timeline and character chart – think of these like a detective's evidence board, where we've been piecing together all the clues. We also need the book review template, which is like a special form to help us share our final thoughts on the whole adventure.

slides.text: Every thread Sachar wove comes together now. The treasure, the families, the curse, the friendship — pay attention to how each piece falls into place. This is the reward for reading closely.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, so this step is super important for understanding how Louis Sachar is a master storyteller. He's been telling us three different stories that seem separate, but now they're all going to crash together. Pay close attention to how the treasure, the Yelnats family history, the Warden's anger, and Stanley and Zero's friendship all start to make sense together. It’s like a puzzle where all the pieces finally click into place.

slides.text: Look at your completed storyline timeline. Every connection you tracked has paid off. Stanley carrying Zero up the mountain broke the curse because it fulfilled the promise Elya Yelnats broke generations ago. Hector Zeroni is a descendant of Madame Zeroni.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see how all those connections we've been tracking on our storyline timeline actually matter! Remember how Stanley carried Zero up the mountain? That wasn't just a nice thing to do; it was the key to breaking the curse that started way back with Elya Yelnats and Madame Zeroni. It shows that Hector Zeroni is actually a descendant of Madame Zeroni, and Stanley's kindness helped fix a mistake from way, way back.

slides.text: Consider Sachar's big question: Is it fate or free will? Were Stanley and Zero destined to end up together, or did their choices create their own redemption? Great literature invites this kind of debate — there is not one right answer.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to think like philosophers! Sachar wants us to wonder if Stanley and Zero were always meant to find each other and break the curse, or if it was their own choices and friendship that made it happen. There isn't one right answer here, so think about what you believe – was it destiny, or did they make their own luck?

slides.text: What makes this a great novel? The intricate structure, the humor, the memorable characters, the themes of justice and friendship, and the way it trusts readers to follow complex connections. Sachar never talks down to his audience.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about why "Holes" is such an amazing book, the kind that wins big awards like the Newbery Medal. It's because Sachar is so clever with how he weaves the stories together, he makes us laugh with his characters, and he trusts us to figure out the complicated parts without him explaining everything. He treats his readers like they're smart enough to follow along.

slides.prompt: Write a book review of 'Holes' that includes: (1) A brief summary without spoiling the ending. (2) Analysis of the novel's structure (three interwoven timelines). (3) Discussion of at least two major themes. (4) Your personal response: what did the book make you think or feel? (5) A rating and recommendation. Support your opinions with specific examples from the text.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to become the critic! You're going to write a review of "Holes." First, give a quick peek at the story without giving away the big ending. Then, talk about how the three different timelines worked together, and pick at least two big ideas from the book, like friendship or justice, to discuss. Most importantly, tell us how the book made *you* feel and what you thought about it, and give it a rating.

slides.text: 'Holes' shows us that the past shapes the present, that friendship can overcome injustice, and that one person's courage can break cycles that have lasted for generations. Carry these ideas with you as you read your next book and as you navigate your own life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain how all three storylines connect, analyze the themes of fate, justice, and friendship, and write a substantive book review with textual evidence?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've reached the end of our journey with "Holes," and this final slide is like a reminder of all the cool stuff we learned. It shows us that what happened in the past really affects today, that sticking by your friends can help fix unfair situations, and that even one brave person can change things for the better, even if it takes generations. Think about these ideas as you start your next book!

parent_notes: Finishing a great book together is a special experience. Take time to discuss the ending — there is a lot to unpack. The question of fate versus free will is genuinely philosophical and can lead to wonderful family conversations. The book review is a culminating assessment that requires both analytical and personal response skills. If your child loved 'Holes,' Louis Sachar's other novels (including 'Small Steps,' a sequel following Armpit) are excellent next reads. Consider keeping the completed storyline timeline as a portfolio piece showing literary analysis skills.

title: Formal Essay Revision — Strengthening Academic Writing
description: Students select a formal essay from earlier in the year and revise it using all the writing skills developed throughout the year. They focus on thesis clarity, evidence integration, paragraph structure, transitions, and academic tone for inclusion in their portfolio.
instructions:
1. Select one formal essay from earlier in the year that could be significantly improved.
2. Reread the essay with fresh eyes, noting strengths and weaknesses.
3. Evaluate the thesis statement: Is it specific, arguable, and clearly stated?
4. Check each body paragraph: Does it have a topic sentence, evidence, analysis, and transition?
5. Apply the 'evidence sandwich' technique to any paragraphs with dropped-in quotes.
6. Strengthen transitions between paragraphs.
7. Check for academic tone: replace informal language, eliminate first person if appropriate.
8. Review the conclusion: Does it go beyond restating the thesis?
9. Edit for grammar, punctuation, and spelling.
10. Write a brief author's note comparing the original and revised versions.

slides.heading: Formal Essay Revision
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this first slide is like the title page for our project. It's telling us we're going to become super-writers by going back to an essay you already wrote and making it way better, like giving it a superhero makeover. We're focusing on making your writing sound really smart and academic.

slides.setup_instructions: Select the essay for revision. Print the revision checklist and transition words reference. Set up a clean workspace for focused writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our toolbox for fixing up your essay. You'll need the essay you wrote before, a checklist to make sure you don't miss anything, a sheet with transition words to help your ideas flow, a red pen for marking things up, and either clean paper or your computer to do the actual revising. Grab those things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: You wrote this essay weeks or months ago. Since then, you have learned new writing techniques, completed a research capstone, and grown as a thinker. Now you can bring all that growth to this earlier piece and transform it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about how much you've learned since you first wrote that essay – you're like a totally different writer now! This step is all about remembering that you've gotten smarter and picked up new tricks for writing. We're going to use all those new skills to take that old essay and make it shine.

slides.text: Start with the big picture: Is the thesis strong? Does each paragraph support it? Is the argument organized logically? Fix structural problems first — there is no point polishing a paragraph that might need to be moved or cut.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like checking the foundation of a house before you paint the walls. We need to make sure your main idea, your thesis, is super clear and that every single paragraph actually helps prove that main idea. It’s better to fix big problems like moving or cutting paragraphs first, before we worry about smaller details.

slides.text: Academic tone means letting the evidence speak rather than just stating your opinion. Instead of 'I think the Roman Empire fell because of corruption,' write 'Historical evidence suggests that internal corruption significantly contributed to the decline of the Roman Empire.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a cool trick for making your writing sound more like a pro. Instead of just saying "I think this," you'll learn to use evidence from your research to show what you mean. So, you'll say something like, "Studies show..." or "Experts agree..." which makes your argument way stronger and more believable.

slides.text: Compare your original conclusion with your capstone conclusion. Apply the techniques you learned: restate the thesis in new words, synthesize (don't just summarize) your arguments, and end with broader significance or a forward-looking thought.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how sometimes your essay felt a little jumpy between ideas? This step is about making those connections super smooth. We'll look at how your conclusion wraps everything up and make sure it's not just repeating what you already said, but leaving the reader with something important to think about.

slides.prompt: Revise your selected formal essay completely. Strengthen the thesis, ensure each body paragraph follows the topic-evidence-analysis structure, improve transitions, refine the academic tone, and craft a stronger conclusion. Then write a brief author's note (3-4 sentences) explaining how the revised version is better than the original and what specific skills you applied.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the main event! You're going to take everything we've talked about and completely rewrite your essay, making that thesis pop, fixing up those paragraphs, smoothing out the transitions, and making sure it sounds super academic. After that, you'll write a short note explaining what you changed and how it made your essay better.

slides.text: The difference between your original essay and this revision is a concrete measure of your growth as a writer. You can now see weaknesses that were invisible to you months ago — that is the definition of learning. This revised essay belongs in your portfolio as evidence of your writing development.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify weaknesses in their earlier writing, apply revision techniques to improve thesis, evidence integration, and tone, and articulate specific improvements in their author's note?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! You just showed how much you've grown as a writer by taking an old piece and making it way stronger. Seeing the difference between your first draft and this revision is proof that you've really learned a lot, and this improved essay is the perfect thing to show off in your portfolio.

parent_notes: This lesson powerfully demonstrates growth. When your child compares the original and revised essays side by side, the improvement is often dramatic and confidence-building. The author's note is metacognitive — it asks your child to reflect on their own learning process. Both the original and revised versions should go in the portfolio to show the journey. If your child is resistant to revising old work, reframe it: they are not fixing a failure; they are showing how much they have grown by bringing new skills to an old piece.

title: Comprehensive Math Review — Fractions, Decimals, and Percentages
description: Students complete a comprehensive review of fraction, decimal, and percentage operations, building fluency for middle school readiness. They work through real-world applications and identify any remaining areas that need practice before the math portfolio.
instructions:
1. Warm up with fraction operations: add, subtract, multiply, and divide fractions with unlike denominators.
2. Review decimal operations: all four operations with decimals, including long division with decimals.
3. Practice converting between fractions, decimals, and percentages.
4. Solve percentage problems: finding a percentage of a number, finding what percentage one number is of another.
5. Apply to real-world scenarios: sales tax, tips, discounts, batting averages.
6. Present word problems that require choosing the correct operation and format.
7. Practice estimation: approximate answers before calculating to check reasonableness.
8. Identify personal strengths and weaknesses across these topics.
9. Students create a study guide for their weakest area.
10. Preview the math portfolio project coming next week.

slides.heading: Comprehensive Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide is just letting us know what we're diving into today. We're going to do a big review of fractions, decimals, and percentages, which are all different ways to talk about parts of a whole. Getting good at these now will totally set you up for success in middle school math.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a comprehensive problem set covering all topics. Have fraction manipulatives available. Print the study guide template.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is our "getting ready" list for today's math adventure. We'll need the problem set with all the practice questions, a calculator to help us double-check, those cool fraction manipulatives to help us see how they work, a whiteboard to jot down our thoughts, graph paper if we need to draw things out, and a study guide template for later. Go grab all these things with a grown-up so we're all set.

slides.text: Fractions, decimals, and percentages are three languages for the same concept: parts of a whole. Today we make sure you are fluent in all three and can translate between them effortlessly.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding that fractions, decimals, and percentages are like different languages that all mean the same thing. Think of it like knowing how to say "hello" in English, Spanish, and French – they all mean the same greeting. Our goal today is to become super fluent in all three and be able to switch between them easily.

slides.text: Fraction review: 3/4 + 2/3 requires a common denominator of 12: 9/12 + 8/12 = 17/12 = 1 5/12. Multiplying fractions is easier: 3/4 x 2/3 = 6/12 = 1/2. Dividing: flip the second fraction and multiply.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is a quick peek at working with fractions. When you add or subtract fractions with different bottoms (denominators), you need to make them the same first, like finding a common language. Multiplying is simpler – you just multiply across, and for dividing, you flip the second fraction and multiply.

slides.text: Real-world application time. A jacket costs $85 and is 30% off. What do you pay? First find 30% of 85: 0.30 x 85 = $25.50. Then subtract: $85 - $25.50 = $59.50. You just used percentages, decimals, and subtraction.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows a super common real-world problem: figuring out discounts! Imagine a jacket is on sale for 30% off. To find out how much you save, you calculate 30% of the original price, which is like multiplying the price by 0.30. Then, you subtract that amount from the original price to find out what you actually pay.

slides.text: ESTIMATION is your secret weapon. Before you calculate, estimate the answer. Is 3/4 + 2/3 more or less than 1? Since each fraction is more than 1/2, the sum must be more than 1. If your exact answer were less than 1, you would know something went wrong.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really important strategy called estimation. Before you do any hard math, try to guess if your answer will be big or small. For the fraction problem, since both 3/4 and 2/3 are bigger than half, you know the answer has to be bigger than 1. This helps you catch mistakes super fast if your final answer seems way off.

slides.prompt: Complete the comprehensive review: (1) 5 fraction operation problems. (2) 5 decimal operation problems. (3) 5 conversion problems (fraction to decimal to percentage). (4) 5 real-world application problems. Estimate each answer before calculating. Then identify your weakest area and create a one-page study guide with key concepts, example problems, and tips for that topic.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show what you know! You'll work through problems with fractions, decimals, and converting between them, plus some real-world stuff like discounts. Remember to estimate your answer first for each one. After that, pick the topic you found trickiest and create a one-page study guide for it, with notes and examples.

slides.text: You have reviewed the core number sense skills that form the foundation for all future mathematics. The areas where you feel confident are ready for middle school. The areas you identified for more practice will be your focus this week. Everyone has areas to strengthen — that is why we review.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student perform operations with fractions, decimals, and percentages, apply them to real-world problems, and identify their own areas for continued practice?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! You've just powered through a ton of important math skills that are the building blocks for everything else. You've gotten stronger in areas you already knew and have a clear plan for the topics you want to focus on more. It's totally normal to have things to practice, and that's exactly what we're doing to get you ready for what's next.

parent_notes: This review helps identify any gaps before the year ends. The self-assessment is key — help your child be honest about what they find difficult rather than rushing to 'get it right.' The study guide they create for their weakest area is a valuable metacognitive exercise. Consider giving real-world practice this week: have them calculate restaurant tips, sale prices, or recipe adjustments. Middle school teachers consistently report that fraction and decimal fluency is the best predictor of algebra success.

title: Science Fair Preparation — Developing Your Question and Hypothesis
description: Students begin preparing for the year-end science fair by selecting a topic, formulating a testable question, developing a hypothesis, and planning their experimental method. They apply the scientific method skills practiced throughout the year.
instructions:
1. Review the scientific method: question, hypothesis, experiment, data, analysis, conclusion.
2. Brainstorm science fair topics based on interests and available materials.
3. Evaluate topics: Is it testable? Is it doable at home? Can you measure the results?
4. Narrow to a final topic and write the research question.
5. Research background information on the topic.
6. Write a hypothesis using the 'If... then... because...' format.
7. Design the experiment: identify variables (independent, dependent, controlled).
8. Plan the materials list and procedure.
9. Create a timeline for the project: research, experiment, analysis, presentation.
10. Discuss safety considerations and get parent approval.

slides.heading: Science Fair Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our science fair adventure! It's telling us that we're going to focus on figuring out a great question to investigate and then making a smart guess about what will happen, which is called a hypothesis. Think of it as setting the stage for your super cool science project.

slides.setup_instructions: Print the science fair guidelines, brainstorming worksheet, and experimental design organizer. Gather reference materials for background research.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to get our tools ready. We've got the science fair guidelines, which are like the rulebook for our project. The brainstorming worksheet will help us come up with ideas, the hypothesis template is a guide for writing our prediction, and the experimental design organizer is where we'll map out how we'll test things. We also need our science journal to keep track of everything, and it's a good idea to have some books or websites handy for background info.

slides.text: The science fair is your chance to investigate something that genuinely interests you. The best projects come from real curiosity — what have you wondered about this year in science? What questions do you still have?
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about tapping into your inner scientist and asking "Why?" or "What if?". Think about all the cool science stuff we've learned this year – what made you go "Whoa!" or what questions popped into your head that you still want answered? Your science fair project should be about something *you're* really curious about.

slides.text: A good science fair question is TESTABLE: you can design an experiment to answer it. 'Why is the sky blue?' is interesting but not testable at home. 'Does the color of light affect plant growth?' IS testable — you can set up the experiment yourself.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, a good science fair question needs to be something you can actually *test* with an experiment. It's like asking if a toy car goes faster down a ramp if you add weight to it – you can totally set that up and see! Asking "Why is the sky blue?" is interesting, but it's too big to test in our classroom or at home, so we need questions we can experiment with.

slides.text: Your hypothesis predicts the answer: 'If plants receive blue light instead of red light, then they will grow taller because blue light has a wavelength most useful for photosynthesis.' The 'because' shows you are not just guessing — you are reasoning from what you know.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains what a hypothesis is: it's your best educated guess about what will happen in your experiment, and it's super important to say *why* you think that. For example, you might predict that a plant will grow taller if it gets more sunlight, *because* plants need sun to make food. It shows you're not just guessing randomly, but thinking through your idea.

slides.text: Design your experiment carefully. The INDEPENDENT variable is what you change. The DEPENDENT variable is what you measure. CONTROLLED variables are everything you keep the same. Good experiments change only one thing at a time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're talking about the key players in your experiment. The independent variable is the one thing *you* change on purpose, and the dependent variable is what you measure to see if it was affected by your change. Controlled variables are all the other things you keep *exactly* the same so they don't mess with your results.

slides.prompt: Complete your science fair preparation: (1) Write your research question. (2) Summarize relevant background research in 3-4 sentences. (3) Write your hypothesis in 'If... then... because...' format. (4) Identify your independent, dependent, and controlled variables. (5) Write a step-by-step procedure. (6) List all materials needed. (7) Create a project timeline.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to put everything together! You'll write down your specific question, do a little bit of reading to understand your topic better, write out your "If... then... because..." hypothesis, and clearly state what you're changing, what you're measuring, and what you're keeping the same. Then, you'll write down the exact steps for your experiment and list everything you'll need.

slides.text: You have laid the groundwork for a genuine scientific investigation. Like real scientists, you started with curiosity, reviewed what is already known, made a prediction, and designed a test. Next session, you will begin your experiment.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student formulate a testable question, write a hypothesis with reasoning, identify variables, and design a clear experimental procedure?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've just built the foundation for an awesome science project! You've figured out what you want to investigate, made a smart prediction with a reason why, and planned out exactly how you'll test it. This is exactly how real scientists start their work, and you're ready to move on to actually doing the experiment next time!

parent_notes: The science fair project should be student-driven. Help with logistics (buying materials, ensuring safety) but let your child make the scientific decisions. The most common pitfall is choosing a topic that is too ambitious — guide them toward something manageable with available materials and time. The hypothesis does not have to be correct; the point is the process of testing it. Review the experimental design for safety issues and discuss any concerns before the experiment begins. This project will take 2-3 weeks to complete.

title: Art Portfolio Compilation — Documenting Your Creative Journey
description: Students begin compiling their art portfolio by reviewing all artwork created throughout the year, selecting their strongest pieces, photographing three-dimensional work, and writing artist's statements that explain their creative choices and growth.
instructions:
1. Gather all artwork from the entire school year.
2. Review each piece, noting the medium, date, skills practiced, and personal response.
3. Organize work chronologically to observe growth over time.
4. Select 8-10 pieces that represent their best work and greatest range.
5. Photograph three-dimensional work and any oversized pieces.
6. Write a brief artist's statement (2-3 sentences) for each selected piece.
7. Create an 'evolution page' showing early and late pieces in the same medium to highlight growth.
8. Design a portfolio cover and table of contents.
9. Arrange pieces in a deliberate order: chronological, by medium, or by theme.
10. Plan any final pieces or additions for the end-of-year show.

slides.heading: Art Portfolio Compilation
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this first slide is just introducing what we're doing today. We're going to put together an art portfolio, which is basically like a scrapbook or a highlight reel of all the amazing art you've made this school year. Think of it as telling the story of your creative journey!

slides.setup_instructions: Collect ALL artwork from the year — check folders, drawers, walls, and digital files. Have a large clean surface for reviewing and organizing. Print artist's statement templates.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our shopping list for building your art portfolio. You'll need all the artwork you've created this year – dig through everything! We also need a portfolio folder to keep it all neat, a camera for any 3D or big pieces, and some special paper for writing about your art.

slides.text: An art portfolio tells the story of your creative journey. It shows not just your best work, but your growth, your range, and your artistic voice. Professional artists maintain portfolios throughout their careers.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is explaining why we even bother with a portfolio. It's not just about showing off your coolest drawings; it's like a visual diary that proves how much you've learned and improved as an artist over the year. Even famous artists keep portfolios!

slides.text: Lay out all your artwork chronologically. Look at the earliest pieces and compare them with the most recent. Can you see your growth? Better technique, stronger composition, more confident use of color and form? That is a year of learning made visible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, for this step, you're going to spread out all your artwork in the order you made it, from the oldest to the newest. This is super important because when you look at them side-by-side, you'll actually be able to *see* how much better you've gotten with your skills, colors, and ideas.

slides.text: Select 8-10 pieces that represent you as an artist. Choose variety: different media, different subjects, different moods. Your portfolio should show range, not just your comfort zone.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is where you become the art curator! You need to pick out about 8 to 10 pieces that you think are your absolute best, but also show that you can do different kinds of art. Don't just pick all the easy ones; pick ones that show off how much you've grown and tried new things.

slides.text: For each piece, write an artist's statement: What is the piece about? What medium and techniques did you use? What were you trying to communicate? What would you do differently now? These statements show that you think deeply about your art.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really cool part where you get to be the expert on your own art. For each piece you choose, you'll write a few sentences explaining what it's about, what materials you used, what you were trying to say with it, and maybe even what you'd change if you made it again. It shows you really think about your art!

slides.prompt: Compile your art portfolio: (1) Select 8-10 pieces representing your best work and greatest range. (2) Photograph any 3D or oversized work. (3) Write artist's statements for at least 5 pieces. (4) Create an 'evolution page' comparing early and recent work in the same medium. (5) Design a cover and table of contents. (6) Arrange pieces in a deliberate order.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the big activity where you put everything together! You'll choose your best 8-10 pieces, take pictures of anything tricky to fit, write those artist statements, and make a special "evolution page" showing how you've improved. Then, you'll design a cool cover and decide the best way to show off your work.

slides.text: Your portfolio is a visual autobiography of your creative year. Every piece in it represents decisions you made, techniques you practiced, and ideas you explored. This is tangible proof of growth, and it is something to be deeply proud of.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student select work based on quality and range, write reflective artist's statements, organize a portfolio with intentional structure, and identify their own artistic growth?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is just a reminder of how awesome your portfolio is. It's like your personal art autobiography, showing all the hard work, learning, and creativity you've put in all year. You should feel super proud of how far you've come and all the amazing art you've made!

parent_notes: Help your child locate ALL their artwork — some pieces may have been stored away and forgotten. The side-by-side comparison of early and recent work is often the most powerful moment in this lesson. Let your child make the selection decisions, but you can ask guiding questions: 'Which piece are you most proud of? Which one taught you the most? Which one would you want to show someone who has never seen your work?' Invest in a nice portfolio folder or binder — presenting work well teaches pride in craftsmanship.

title: Smart Consumer Skills — Evaluating Products and Advertisements
description: Students develop critical consumer skills by analyzing advertising techniques, comparing products for value, reading reviews critically, and understanding how marketing influences purchasing decisions. They apply budgeting skills from the previous week to make informed choices.
instructions:
1. Discuss the purpose of advertising: to persuade you to buy something.
2. Identify common advertising techniques: emotional appeal, celebrity endorsement, bandwagon, fear of missing out, repetition, humor.
3. Analyze 5-6 advertisements (print, video, or online) and identify the techniques used in each.
4. Discuss the difference between needs-based purchasing and impulse buying.
5. Introduce price comparison: unit price, quality assessment, brand versus generic.
6. Practice calculating unit prices to find the better deal.
7. Discuss online reviews: how to spot fake reviews, what to look for in trustworthy reviews.
8. Role-play a smart shopping scenario: compare three products and make a justified choice.
9. Connect to budgeting: How do consumer skills help you stick to a budget?
10. Create a 'Smart Consumer Checklist' for future purchasing decisions.

slides.heading: Smart Consumer Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our lesson, telling us we're going to become super smart shoppers! We'll learn how to figure out if products and their ads are actually as good as they seem, and how to make sure we're spending our money wisely.

slides.setup_instructions: Collect 5-6 advertisements from magazines, websites, or video. Prepare product comparison data for a common item (cereal, sneakers, or headphones) at different brands and price points.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things to help us become advertising detectives. You'll need some ads, like from magazines or online, so we can poke them apart. We'll also have some charts to compare products, a calculator to help with math, examples of online reviews, a template to make our own checklist, and some play money to pretend we're shopping. Ask a grown-up to help you gather these items.

slides.text: Companies spend billions of dollars on advertising because it works. Understanding HOW it works gives you power. Once you can see the techniques, advertisements lose their ability to manipulate you.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains why we're even learning this stuff: companies spend a TON of money trying to get you to buy their products, and they're really good at it! But once we know the tricks they use, like how they try to make you feel a certain way, their ads won't be able to trick us anymore, and we'll be in charge of our money.

slides.text: Watch for these techniques: EMOTIONAL APPEAL (making you feel happy, sad, or scared), BANDWAGON ('everyone is buying it'), CELEBRITY ENDORSEMENT (a famous person uses it), and FEAR OF MISSING OUT ('limited time offer!'). Once you name the technique, you see through it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're going to learn some specific advertising tricks. Watch out for ads that try to make you feel happy or sad (that's emotional appeal), ads that say "everyone's doing it!" (that's the bandwagon effect), or when a famous person tells you to buy something (celebrity endorsement). They might also try to make you feel like you'll miss out if you don't buy something fast.

slides.text: When comparing products, look at the UNIT PRICE — the cost per ounce, per item, or per serving. A larger package is not always a better deal. Calculate: 12 oz for $3.60 is $0.30/oz, while 8 oz for $2.00 is $0.25/oz. The smaller package is actually cheaper per ounce!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important trick for saving money: checking the *unit price*. It means figuring out how much you're paying for *each* ounce or *each* item, not just the total price. Sometimes the bigger box looks like a better deal, but if you do the math, the smaller one might actually be cheaper per ounce, like in the example on the slide.

slides.text: Online reviews can be helpful or misleading. Look for RED FLAGS in fake reviews: overly enthusiastic language, very short reviews, reviews posted on the same day, or reviews that do not mention specific features. Trustworthy reviews mention both positives and negatives.
slides.mascot_explanation: When you're shopping online, you'll see lots of reviews, but some aren't real! Watch out for reviews that sound *too* excited, are super short, or all seem to show up at the same time. The best reviews are the ones that talk about both good and bad things, so you get the real story.

slides.prompt: Analyze three advertisements and identify the technique(s) used in each. Then compare three versions of the same product: calculate unit prices, evaluate quality indicators, and read sample reviews. Make a purchasing decision and justify it in writing. Finally, create your personal Smart Consumer Checklist with at least 7 questions to ask before buying something.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put on your detective hats! You'll look at three ads and figure out the tricks they're using, then compare three different versions of the same product – maybe cereal or headphones – by checking their unit prices and reading those reviews we talked about. After that, you'll decide which one is the best buy and write down why, and then create your own list of questions to ask yourself before you buy anything.

slides.text: Being a smart consumer is about making informed choices, not about never buying anything. When you understand advertising techniques, compare prices, and read reviews critically, you spend your money on what truly matters to you instead of what marketers want you to buy.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify advertising techniques, calculate unit prices for comparison, evaluate product reviews critically, and make justified purchasing decisions?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, being a smart shopper isn't about *never* buying stuff; it's about making sure you're buying things you really need or want, and not just because an ad told you to. By knowing the tricks, comparing prices, and reading reviews, you'll be able to spend your money on the things that are actually important to you.

parent_notes: Consumer literacy is immediately applicable. Next time you shop together, have your child practice comparing unit prices, identifying advertising techniques in store displays, or reading product reviews together. The Smart Consumer Checklist becomes a real tool they can use. These skills connect directly to the budgeting lesson — making good purchasing decisions is how budgets work in practice. Discuss how your family makes purchasing decisions without making it feel like finances are stressful. The goal is empowerment, not anxiety.

title: Creative Writing Anthology — Assembling and Introducing Your Collection
description: Students finalize their creative writing anthology by assembling revised pieces, writing author's notes for each selection, crafting a personal introduction, and designing a cover. The completed anthology becomes a centerpiece of their year-end portfolio.
instructions:
1. Assemble all revised pieces in the chosen order.
2. Write or finalize author's notes for each remaining piece.
3. Craft a personal introduction: Who are you as a writer? What themes do you return to? How have you grown?
4. Design a cover: title, author name, and illustration or design.
5. Create a dedication page: who is this anthology for?
6. Write an 'About the Author' page with a brief biographical statement.
7. Assemble all pages in order: cover, dedication, introduction, table of contents, pieces with author's notes.
8. Number pages and finalize the table of contents.
9. Do a final proofread of the entire anthology.
10. Celebrate the completion with a reading of one piece to an audience.

slides.heading: Creative Writing Anthology
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this first slide is just like the title page of a book, introducing what we're doing. It's called "Creative Writing Anthology," which basically means we're putting together a collection of our best writing from this year, like a mini-book of our own stories, poems, or whatever we've written.

slides.setup_instructions: Have all revised pieces in order. Prepare blank pages for the cover, dedication, introduction, and about the author. Have binding or stapling materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us all the stuff we need to make our anthologies look and feel like real books. We've got our revised writing pieces, some blank pages for adding new parts, art supplies to make a cool cover, and things like staples or glue to hold it all together. Make sure you have all these ready to go before we start putting everything together!

slides.text: Today you assemble your anthology — a real book that you wrote, curated, and designed. This is a creative accomplishment that few people your age (or any age) achieve. Take it seriously and take pride in it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this step is all about understanding the big picture. We're actually putting our finished books together today, and it's a really big deal! Think about it – you're creating your very own published work, which is something super impressive that shows off all your hard work and creativity this year.

slides.text: Your introduction tells readers who you are as a writer. What topics and themes keep appearing in your work? What do you love about writing? What was your biggest challenge this year? What piece are you most proud of? Write honestly and personally.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to write the introduction to our book, and this is where we get to tell people who *we* are as writers. Think about what kind of stories you like to tell, what ideas you keep coming back to in your writing, and how you've gotten better at writing this year. Be honest and let your personality shine through!

slides.text: Every book has a dedication. Think about who has supported your writing this year — a parent, a sibling, a friend, a teacher, or even a fictional character who inspired you. A dedication is a gift of gratitude.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next part is like a special thank you note in our book. Every book has a dedication page, and it's a chance to thank someone who helped you out, maybe a parent, a friend, or even a character from a book who inspired you. It's a small way to show you appreciate their support.

slides.text: Your 'About the Author' page should sound like a real author bio. Write in the third person: '[Name] is a [age]-year-old writer who lives in [place]. Their favorite genres are... This is their first published anthology.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're writing a little bio about ourselves, like you see in real books. You'll write it in the third person, talking about yourself as if someone else is introducing you. Mention your age, where you live, what kind of writing you enjoy, and that this is your first big collection.

slides.prompt: Assemble your complete anthology: (1) Design and create the cover. (2) Write the dedication page. (3) Write the personal introduction. (4) Finalize the table of contents with page numbers. (5) Include all pieces with author's notes. (6) Write the 'About the Author' page. (7) Bind or staple the anthology. (8) Do a final proofread. Then read your favorite piece aloud to celebrate.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event – we're actually putting our whole anthology together now! We'll design the cover, write the dedication and intro, make sure our table of contents is correct with page numbers, add all our stories with those author's notes we wrote, and then put our "About the Author" page in. After we bind it all up, we'll do one last check and then celebrate by reading our favorite piece aloud.

slides.text: You have created a book. Not a school assignment, not a worksheet — a real creative work that reflects a year of growth, practice, and self-expression. Keep this anthology. Years from now, it will be a window into who you were at this moment in your life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student assemble a complete, organized anthology with cover, dedication, introduction, table of contents, author's notes, and author biography?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! You've officially created your very own book, not just an assignment. This anthology is a real piece of art that shows how much you've grown as a writer and as a person this year. Keep this special book safe because it's a snapshot of you right now.

parent_notes: This is a milestone worth celebrating. Consider making copies for grandparents or other family members who would treasure a handmade book by your child. If you have access to a printer and binding supplies, a more professional presentation adds to the sense of accomplishment. The personal introduction is often the most revealing piece — it shows how your child sees themselves as a writer. Save this anthology carefully; it is irreplaceable and will only become more meaningful with time.

title: Math Portfolio — Documenting Your Mathematical Journey
description: Students begin compiling a math portfolio that showcases their growth, skills, and mathematical thinking from the year. They select representative work, write explanations of their problem-solving strategies, and reflect on their development as mathematical thinkers.
instructions:
1. Discuss what a math portfolio shows: not just answers, but thinking, growth, and problem-solving.
2. Gather math work from throughout the year: tests, projects, problem sets, graphs.
3. Select 8-10 pieces that represent key skills and growth moments.
4. For each selected piece, write a brief explanation: What skill does this show? Why did you choose it?
5. Create a 'growth comparison' page: show an early attempt and a later success in the same skill area.
6. Solve one new 'challenge problem' that demonstrates advanced thinking.
7. Write a mathematical autobiography: How has your relationship with math changed this year?
8. Create a skills checklist showing mastery levels for each major topic.
9. Design a cover and organize the portfolio.
10. Set three math goals for middle school.
materials_needed: Math work from throughout the year

slides.heading: Math Portfolio
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page for our big project: your math portfolio! Think of it like a scrapbook or a highlight reel, but for all the cool math stuff you've learned and done this year. It’s going to show off how much you’ve grown, not just what answers you got right.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all math work from the year. Print the skills checklist and challenge problem. Prepare the portfolio folder with dividers for different sections.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what we need to gather for our portfolio. We've got your old math papers, tests, and projects – that's the "math work from the year." The "portfolio folder" is like the binder that will hold everything together, and the "skills checklist" and "challenge problem sheet" are special papers we'll use later. Make sure to grab some lined paper and colored pencils too, for writing and decorating!

slides.text: A math portfolio is different from an art portfolio because it shows your THINKING, not just your answers. For each piece you select, the explanation of HOW you solved it and WHY it matters is as important as the solution itself.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because it tells us what makes a math portfolio special. It's not just about showing the right answers, like in a test. It's about showing *how* you figured things out, like your step-by-step thinking and any cool strategies you used. Your teacher wants to see your brain working, not just the final result.

slides.text: Choose pieces that show range: include fractions, geometry, statistics, algebra, and problem-solving. Also choose pieces that show growth — maybe a topic that was hard at first but you mastered by the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, for this part, we need to be smart about what we pick for our portfolio. Look through all your math work and choose papers that show different kinds of math, like adding fractions or solving word problems. Also, try to find stuff where you started off finding it tough but then you really got it later on – that shows you're a great learner!

slides.text: The growth comparison is the most powerful part. Find an early piece where you struggled and a later piece where you succeeded in the same skill. Side by side, these tell the story of your persistence and learning.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is talking about one of the most awesome parts of the portfolio: showing how you've grown. You'll find an old paper where you maybe struggled with a math idea, and then a newer paper where you totally nailed that same idea. Putting them next to each other is like showing a "before and after" picture of your math skills, proving you stuck with it and got better.

slides.text: Your mathematical autobiography should be honest. Did you start the year loving math? Hating it? Somewhere in between? What changed? What are you proud of? What still challenges you? Mathematicians are always growing.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next step is about you writing a short story about your math journey this year. Be honest about whether you loved math from the start, or if you found it tricky. Think about what made you feel proud, what was hard, and how your feelings about math might have changed. It’s like telling your own math adventure story!

slides.prompt: Build your math portfolio: (1) Select 8-10 pieces representing key skills. (2) Write explanations for each selection. (3) Create a growth comparison page. (4) Solve the challenge problem with complete work shown. (5) Write your mathematical autobiography (1 page). (6) Complete the skills self-assessment checklist. (7) Write three math goals for middle school.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we actually build the portfolio! You’ll pick about 8 to 10 pieces of your best math work, write down why you chose them and how you solved them, and then make that cool "growth comparison" page. Don't forget to solve the tricky challenge problem, write your math story, fill out the skills checklist, and set those middle school goals. You've got this!

slides.text: Your math portfolio captures a year of growth, struggle, and triumph. Mathematics is not about being fast or never making mistakes — it is about thinking deeply, persisting through challenges, and growing from every attempt. Your portfolio proves you have done all of that.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student select representative math work, explain their problem-solving strategies, identify growth areas, and articulate mathematical goals?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the wrap-up slide, celebrating all your hard work! Your portfolio isn't just a collection of papers; it's proof that you thought hard, worked through challenges, and got better at math all year long. It shows you’re a real mathematician because you know that learning involves trying, sometimes messing up, and always growing.

parent_notes: Math portfolios are less common than writing portfolios but equally valuable. Help your child locate math work from early in the year — the contrast with current abilities is often striking. The mathematical autobiography is especially important for children who have had a complicated relationship with math. Whether they started the year confident or anxious, documenting their journey validates their effort. The middle school goals give them ownership of their continued learning. Save this portfolio alongside the writing anthology and art portfolio.

title: Oral History Project — Interviewing Someone About Their Lived Experience
description: Students learn oral history methodology and conduct an interview with a family member, neighbor, or community member about their life experiences. They connect personal stories to larger historical events and preserve living history through careful documentation.
instructions:
1. Introduce oral history: the practice of recording people's memories and stories before they are lost.
2. Discuss why oral history matters: it captures perspectives often missing from textbooks.
3. Teach interviewing skills: open-ended questions, active listening, follow-up questions, respectful silence.
4. Develop 10 interview questions, mixing factual (When were you born?) with reflective (What was the most important moment in your life?).
5. Practice interviewing technique with a partner.
6. Discuss recording methods: written notes, audio recording (with permission), video.
7. Conduct the interview (or schedule it for the coming days).
8. After the interview, identify connections between the person's story and historical events studied this year.
9. Write a short narrative based on the interview.
10. Reflect on what you learned that you could never find in a textbook.

slides.heading: Oral History Project
slides.subheading: Interviewing Someone About Their Lived Experience
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is introducing our big project: an Oral History Project! It means we're going to learn how to talk to people and record their life stories, kind of like being a detective for memories. We're going to interview someone about what their life was like, which is super cool because it's history that isn't just in books.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the interview question template. Identify the interviewee and schedule the conversation. Test any recording equipment. Have thank you card supplies ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide lists everything we'll need for our interviews. We've got a template to help us write our questions, a notebook to jot things down, and a recording device to capture the conversation (but only if they say it's okay!). There's also a sheet with tips, supplies to make a thank you card, and paper to write our story later. Make sure you gather all these things, and ask a grown-up for help if you need to!

slides.text: History is not just in books — it is in the memories of the people around you. Your grandparents, neighbors, and community members have lived through historical events. Oral history preserves their stories before they are forgotten.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding *why* we're doing this. Think about all the history we learn in class – usually, it's from books. But this project is about realizing that real history happened to real people, like your parents or grandparents, and their memories are super valuable! Oral history is our way of making sure those personal stories don't get lost over time.

slides.text: Good interview questions are OPEN-ENDED: they cannot be answered with just yes or no. Instead of 'Did you like school?' ask 'What was school like when you were my age?' Instead of 'Were you happy?' ask 'What brought you the most joy during that time?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about asking good questions, because that's key to getting great stories! The slide explains "open-ended questions," which basically means questions that can't be answered with just a "yes" or "no." Instead of asking "Did you have fun at the park?", you'd ask "What was your favorite thing to do at the park?" This encourages them to tell you more!

slides.text: The best interviewers listen more than they talk. After asking a question, be comfortable with silence — the interviewee may need time to think. If they say something interesting, ask 'Can you tell me more about that?' Follow-up questions lead to the best stories.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about being a great listener. It's easy to want to fill up every silence, but sometimes, people need a moment to remember or think. The best interviewers wait patiently, and if something really interesting pops up, they ask "Can you tell me more about that?" This is how you get the really juicy details and the best stories!

slides.text: Always ask permission before recording. Be respectful of topics the person does not want to discuss. At the end, thank them sincerely — they have given you a gift by sharing their memories.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important step about being respectful during the interview. Always, always ask permission before you hit record on your device – it's only polite! Also, if someone seems uncomfortable talking about something, don't push them; just move on to another question. And at the very end, a big thank you is essential because they're sharing something really special with you.

slides.prompt: Develop your 10 interview questions (mix factual, experiential, and reflective questions). Practice your interviewing technique with a partner. If your interviewee is available today, conduct the interview. If not, finalize your preparation and schedule the interview for the coming days. After the interview, write a one-page narrative highlighting the most interesting stories and connecting them to historical events you have studied.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put it all together! You need to come up with 10 interview questions, mixing up simple facts with deeper thoughts. Then, practice asking them with a friend to get the hang of it. If your person is ready, do the interview now, or get it scheduled! After you talk to them, you'll write a story using the coolest parts of what they told you and connect it to history.

slides.text: Oral history reminds us that behind every historical event are real people with real experiences. The stories you collect today might be the only record of those memories. You are doing something genuinely important — preserving human history one conversation at a time.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student develop thoughtful open-ended interview questions, demonstrate active listening during an interview, and connect personal stories to larger historical events?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is a reminder of how awesome you're being! You're not just learning history; you're actually *collecting* it by listening to real people's experiences. These memories are precious and might be the only place they exist, so you're doing something really important by saving them, one conversation at a time.

parent_notes: This project often becomes one of the most meaningful experiences of the year. Help your child identify an interviewee — grandparents are ideal, but neighbors, family friends, or community elders also work well. The interview might uncover family stories your child has never heard. If the interviewee agrees, recording the conversation preserves it for future generations. The thank you card is important — model gratitude for the gift of someone's time and memories. Some children discover a genuine passion for oral history through this project.

title: Science Fair — Conducting the Experiment and Collecting Data
description: Students conduct their science fair experiments, carefully following their planned procedures, recording data accurately, and documenting observations. They practice the disciplined data collection that distinguishes scientific inquiry from casual observation.
instructions:
1. Review the experimental design: question, hypothesis, variables, and procedure.
2. Gather all materials and set up the experiment.
3. Discuss the importance of following the procedure exactly as written.
4. Begin the experiment, recording data in a pre-designed data table.
5. Take photographs at each major step for the presentation board.
6. Record qualitative observations (descriptions) alongside quantitative data (numbers).
7. If the experiment has multiple trials, discuss why repetition strengthens results.
8. Note any unexpected events or deviations from the procedure.
9. Ensure data is organized, labeled, and legible.
10. Discuss preliminary observations: Do early results support or challenge the hypothesis?
materials_needed: Measuring tools (ruler, scale, thermometer as needed)

slides.heading: Science Fair
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our science adventure today! It's telling us we're moving on to the exciting part of our science fair project: actually *doing* the experiment and collecting all the important information. Think of it as the start of your mission to uncover something new.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all experiment materials. Print or prepare the data collection table. Set up the experiment area with adequate space and lighting for photography.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything you'll need to be a super scientist today. You've got your project materials, a data table to keep track of your findings, a science journal for notes, a camera to capture what's happening, measuring tools like rulers or scales, and a timer. Make sure you gather all these with a grown-up's help before we start.

slides.text: Today you become a real scientist conducting a real experiment. The key to good science is CAREFUL, HONEST data collection. Record exactly what happens, not what you hope will happen. Science values truth above all else.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important for being a real scientist. It means you have to be really honest and careful when you write down what happens in your experiment. Don't write down what you *wish* would happen, write down *exactly* what you see, even if it's weird or surprising, because scientists always look for the truth.

slides.text: Follow your procedure step by step. If something unexpected happens, do not panic — write it down. Some of the greatest scientific discoveries came from unexpected results. The penicillin mold was an 'accident' that changed medicine.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to actually *do* your experiment, following the instructions you wrote down, step-by-step. If something unexpected pops up, don't freak out – just jot it down in your journal! Sometimes those "oops" moments lead to the coolest discoveries, like how scientists found penicillin by accident.

slides.text: Record TWO types of observations: QUANTITATIVE (numbers you can measure — temperature, height, time, weight) and QUALITATIVE (descriptions — color changes, texture, smell, behavior). Both types of data tell important parts of the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a cool trick scientists use: they record two kinds of information. First, there are the *quantitative* numbers you can measure, like how hot something got or how long it took. Then there are the *qualitative* observations, which are descriptions of what you see, smell, or feel, like if a color changes or if something feels sticky.

slides.text: Take photographs at every stage. Your presentation board will need visual documentation showing the setup, the process, and the results. Good documentation lets other scientists understand and potentially repeat your experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be a photographer! You need to take pictures as you go through each major part of your experiment – from setting it up to seeing the results. These photos are like proof of what you did and will make your science fair board look awesome because they show everyone exactly how you did your experiment.

slides.prompt: Conduct your science fair experiment following your written procedure exactly. Record all data in your prepared data table. Take photographs at each major step. Write detailed qualitative observations alongside your quantitative measurements. Note any unexpected events or deviations from the plan.
