If your experiment requires multiple days, set up today and plan your ongoing data collection schedule.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you put on your scientist hat and *do* your experiment! Follow your plan carefully, write down all your measurements in your data table, and snap photos of each big step. Also, don't forget to write down those descriptions of what's happening, and if anything strange happens, make a note of it.

slides.text: You have real data from a real experiment. Whether or not the results match your hypothesis, you have practiced genuine scientific inquiry. Next, you will analyze this data, draw conclusions, and prepare your presentation.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student follow an experimental procedure accurately, record quantitative and qualitative data, document the process photographically, and note unexpected observations?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've collected real data from your very own experiment, which is awesome. It doesn't matter if the results were exactly what you predicted or totally different, you've learned how to be a real scientist by carefully observing and recording. Next, we'll figure out what all that information means.

parent_notes: Supervise the experiment for safety but let your child do the work. Resist the temptation to 'fix' the experiment if results seem wrong — unexpected results are scientifically valuable. Help with any aspects that require adult hands (cutting, using heat sources, handling chemicals). The photo documentation is important for the presentation board. If the experiment requires multiple days, help your child maintain a consistent schedule. Remind them to record data at the same time each day for experiments tracking change over time.

title: Concert Rehearsal — Polishing and Performance Readiness
description: Students polish their ensemble concert repertoire with focused rehearsal on difficult passages, transitions, and overall performance quality. They practice the complete program with performance etiquette and prepare for the end-of-year show.
instructions:
1. Review the feedback from the previous rehearsal recording.
2. Warm up with focused exercises targeting identified weak spots.
3. Isolate and drill the most challenging passages of each piece.
4. Practice transitions between pieces: how to end one song and begin the next smoothly.
5. Work on dynamics: louder and softer moments create emotional impact.
6. Practice audience interaction: introductions, acknowledgments, and bowing.
7. Discuss managing performance anxiety: deep breathing, positive self-talk, focusing on the music.
8. Do a complete run-through of the program in performance mode.
9. Record the run-through and listen back for final adjustments.
10. Discuss any last changes before the performance date.

slides.heading: Concert Rehearsal
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our concert rehearsal. It tells us that we're going to spend this time really fine-tuning everything, making sure our music sounds as polished and professional as possible for the big performance. Think of it like making sure all the details are perfect before a big party!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the performance space to match the actual venue as closely as possible. Have the previous recording available for review. Check that all instruments are tuned.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the stuff we need to have ready. We've got our sheet music with all the notes, our instruments to play them on, and a recording device to listen back to ourselves later. We also need our performance space set up to feel like a real stage, and that checklist for our concert outfits. Go grab all these things so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Professional musicians spend 90% of rehearsal time on the 10% of music that is most difficult. Let's identify the spots that need the most work and drill them until they feel confident.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important tip from pro musicians: they spend most of their practice time on the parts that are actually the hardest. So, on this slide, we need to figure out which bits in our songs are tricky for us, and then we're going to play those parts over and over until they feel easy. It’s like practicing the hardest part of a video game until you can beat it every time.

slides.text: Dynamics bring music to life. Playing everything at the same volume is like speaking in a monotone. Mark your music: where should you be loud? Where should you be soft? Where should you gradually get louder or softer? These choices make the performance emotional and memorable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about dynamics, which means playing loud and soft parts. If you only play at one volume, it sounds kind of boring, right? So, we need to look at our music and mark where we should play strongly and where we should play gently. This is how we make the music exciting and really connect with the people listening.

slides.text: Performance anxiety is normal — even professional musicians feel nervous. Here are proven strategies: take three deep breaths before starting, focus on the music rather than the audience, remember that the audience wants you to succeed, and channel nervous energy into expressive performance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Feeling nervous before performing is totally normal, even for famous musicians! This slide gives us some cool tricks to handle those jitters. We'll practice taking deep breaths to calm down, focusing on the music itself instead of thinking about the audience, and remembering that everyone wants us to do well. It's about using that nervous energy to make our performance even better.

slides.text: This is our dress rehearsal. Treat it like the real thing: walk on stage, introduce the program, perform every piece, handle transitions, and bow at the end. If something goes wrong, keep going — that is what professionals do.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our big practice run-through, like a dress rehearsal! We need to act just like we will on the real performance day. That means walking onto the "stage," introducing our music, playing every song all the way through, and remembering to bow at the end. If you make a mistake, the key is to just keep playing – that's what real pros do!

slides.prompt: Complete a full dress rehearsal of the concert program. Perform from start to finish without stopping, including entrances, transitions, introductions, and bows. Record the entire run-through. Then listen back and identify: two things that went well and two final adjustments to make before the performance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our main activity: performing the whole concert program from start to finish, just like we'll do for the audience. We need to record the whole thing so we can watch it back afterward. After we finish, we'll figure out two things we did really well and two small things we can still improve before the actual show.

slides.text: You are performance-ready. The preparation you have done — learning parts, blending as an ensemble, working on dynamics, and managing anxiety — is exactly what professional musicians do. Trust your preparation and enjoy the performance.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student perform their repertoire accurately with appropriate dynamics, handle transitions smoothly, demonstrate performance etiquette, and manage performance anxiety?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is saying "Great job!" You've worked hard on your music, played together as a group, practiced loud and soft parts, and learned how to stay calm. All of that is exactly what professional musicians do, so you are totally ready. Just remember all your practice, trust yourself, and have fun during the performance!

parent_notes: The dress rehearsal should feel as close to the real performance as possible. If other family members can serve as a small audience, that helps with performance anxiety practice. Listen to the recording together and offer specific, positive feedback before suggesting improvements. Performance anxiety tips (deep breathing, positive self-talk) are life skills that apply far beyond music. Discuss what to wear and logistical details for the actual performance so there are no surprises on the day.
